revision.text:
{{Short description|French actress}} {{More citations needed|date = December 2019}} {{Infobox person | name = Claudine Auger | image = Domino Vitali by Claudine Auger.jpg | caption = Claudine Auger as Domino in ''[[Thunderball (film)|Thunderball]]'' (1965) | birth_name = Claudine Oger | birth_date = {{Birth date|1941|04|26||df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Paris]], [[German military administration in occupied France during World War II|German-occupied France]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2019|12|18|1941|04|26||df=yes}} | death_place = Paris, France | children = 1 | occupation = Actress | years_active = 1958–1995 | spouse = Pierre Gaspard-Huit
(m. 1959; div. ????)
Peter Brent
(m. ????; his death 2008) }} '''Claudine Auger''' (born '''Claudine Oger'''; 26 April 1941 – 18 December 2019) was a French actress best known for her role as [[Bond girl]], [[Domino Vitali|Dominique "Domino" Derval]], in the [[James Bond]] film ''[[Thunderball (film)|Thunderball]]'' (1965). She earned the title of [[Miss France Monde]] (the French representative of [[Miss World]]) and was also the first runner-up in the [[Miss World 1958|1958 Miss World]] contest. == Early life == Auger was born in [[Paris]], France. She attended St. Joan of Arc College and later the [[Conservatoire de Paris]], where she performed dramatic roles. She made her film debut when she was still in school. == Career == [[Jean Cocteau]] cast Auger in an uncredited role as a tall ballerina in ''[[Testament of Orpheus]]'' (1960). When she was 18, she married the 43-year-old writer-director [[Pierre Gaspard-Huit]], and he cast her in several films, including ''[[Le Masque de fer]]'' (1962) and ''[[Kali Yug: Goddess of Vengeance]]'' (1963).Tom Lisanti and Louis Paul, ''Film Fatales: Women in Espionage Films and Television, 1962-1973''. McFarland and Company, Inc. Publishers (2002), p. 46 In 1966 she co-starred in the [[World War II]] drama ''[[Triple Cross (1966 film)|Triple Cross]]'' with [[Yul Brynner]] and [[Christopher Plummer]]. When she was on holiday in [[Nassau, Bahamas|Nassau]], writer-producer [[Kevin McClory]] saw her and recommended that she audition for his film ''[[Thunderball (film)|Thunderball]]'' (1965). The role of Domino was originally to be an Italian woman, Dominetta Petacchi. Auger impressed the producers so much that they rewrote the part to that of a French woman, to better suit Auger. Although she took lessons to perfect her English, her voice was eventually dubbed by [[Nikki van der Zyl]].{{cn|date=May 2020}} Auger would claim that she related to her character Domino, as she and Domino were both involved with older men.{{cn|date=May 2020}} The most immediate byproduct of Claudine's stardom was a semi-nude ''[[Playboy]]'' spread. ''Thunderball'' launched Auger into a successful European movie career, but did little for her otherwise in the [[United States]].{{Cite news| title = Bond Was No Boost For Auger | url= https://articles.latimes.com/1986-11-29/entertainment/ca-16048_1_claudine-auger| first= Roderick | last= Mann | date= 29 November 1986 | access-date= 21 July 2012 | work=Los Angeles Times}} She did, however, star in a [[Danny Thomas]] special called ''The Road to Lebanon'' with [[Bing Crosby]], which was shown on NBC on 20 April 1966.{{Cite web|last1=Pairpoint|first1=Lionel|title=The Chronological Bing Crosby on Television|url=http://www.bingmagazine.co.uk/bingmagazine/BingTV.htm|website=BING magazine|access-date=February 22, 2016}} Auger co-starred with another [[Bond girl]], [[Ursula Andress]], in the Italian comedy ''[[Anyone Can Play]]'' (1968). She starred with two future [[Bond girl]]s, [[Barbara Bouchet]] and [[Barbara Bach]], in ''[[Black Belly of the Tarantula]]'' (1971), a [[giallo]] mystery. She had some roles in European films such as ''[[Triple Cross (1966 film)|Triple Cross]]'' (1966, reuniting her with her James Bond director [[Terence Young (director)|Terence Young]]), and ''[[The Killing Game (1967 film)|The Killing Game]]'' (1967).{{Cite news |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/person/2828/Claudine-Auger/biography |title=Claudine Auger |first=Hal |last=Erickson |publisher=NYTimes.com | work=All Movie Guide}} Auger appeared in the British television series ''[[Sherlock Holmes (1984 TV series)|The Memoirs of Sherlock Holmes]]'', in "The Three Gables" (1994), as Isadora Klein, in one of the last episodes of the series. == Personal life and death == In 1959, she married writer-director [[Pierre Gaspard-Huit]]. They later divorced. She married British businessman Peter Brent{{Cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/kiss-death-article-1.694430 |title=Kiss of Death |first= Michael|last= Riedel |work=New York Daily News |date=November 12, 1995}} in the 1980s. The couple had one child, Jessica Claudine Brent (b. 1991). Peter Brent died in August 2008. Auger died in Paris on 18 December 2019 following a lengthy illness.{{Cite web |title=Claudine Auger: French actress known for James Bond role dies aged 78 |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-50864159 |publisher=BBC News |date=20 December 2019 |access-date=20 December 2019}}{{Cite web |title=Thunderball actress Claudine Auger has died aged 78 |url=https://www.rte.ie/entertainment/2019/1220/1102286-thunderball-actress-claudine-auger-has-died-aged-78/ |publisher=RTE |date=20 December 2019 |access-date=20 December 2019}}{{Cite web |last1=Milkelbank |first1=Peter |title=Claudine Auger, First French Actress to Star as a Bond Girl, Dies at 78 |url=https://people.com/movies/bond-girl-claudine-auger-dies/ |work=People |date=19 December 2019 |access-date=20 December 2019}}https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/claudine-auger-dead-bond-girl-thunderball-was-78-1264424 == Filmography == {| class="wikitable" ! style="background:
